awd_titl_txt: Scalable Quantum Emitters Enabled through Rational Bottom-Up Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Light sources that emit a stream of identical particles of light are critical for the advancement of light-based quantum technologies. These technologies include secure quantum communication and light-based quantum computing. Light from such sources is referred to as quantum light. Bright sources of quantum light will enable optical technologies that are unachievable with today's classical light sources, much as the development of lasers paved the way for key innovations in science and led to a large body of essential commercial applications. The research team focuses on the development of nanoparticles that can emit quantum light. These nanoparticles can be made in solution and in quantity, paving the way for the production of large numbers of identical quantum light sources. Engaging and retaining women and underrepresented minorities (URMs) in the sciences is a systemic challenge the team addresses through a variety of complementary efforts. The project encompasses pre-college outreach programs targeting K-12 students and the broader community, fostering exposure and excitement about the science conducted. Undergraduates are encouraged to obtain research experience preparing them for graduate school through a set of initiatives, especially focusing on URM students. 

The project aims to develop lead halide perovskite nanocrystals capable of serving as single photon sources to enable a broad range of quantum information technology applications. The project follows a multifaceted approach combining chemical exploration of composition, shape, size and ligand environment together with computational modeling. The interplay between computational exploration and chemical synthesis allows for the design and synthesis of colloidal quantum emitters that can serve as building blocks in nano-electronic devices in a rational and scalable fashion. Current lead halide perovskite nanocrystals suffer from two main shortcomings with respect to coherent single photon emission, namely instability of the lattice and competitive dephasing. The team synthesizes and investigates new ligands and inorganic shells to suppress the dynamic twinning within the crystal and to rigidify the lattice to diminish phononic coupling, aiming to increase photon coherence times. Optimizations in composition and geometry are explored to yield faster lifetimes and improved photon purity. Construction of colloidal nano-assemblies are used to decrease lifetimes, paving the way for the development of a family of emitters with transform limited emission. Establishing this colloidal system as a viable source of quantum light critically expands the toolbox of quantum photonics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The development of light sources has provided a consistent contribution to the progress of humanity for centuries. In this project, we aimed to move beyond classical light emitters, and establish colloidal perovskite quantum dots (PQDs) as a new class of high-performance quantum emitter. To this end, we investigated the influence of a range of synthetic strategies on the optical properties of PQDs, with the goal of realizing an emitter displaying fast radiative rates, deterministic generation of single photons, a high degree of coherence for each photon, and high stability under operating conditions. In particular, ligands tailored to the PQD surface were hypothesized to have beneficial effects on the optical properties, and this is proven in our work. 

A set of tetraalkylammonium based ligands was synthesized exploring the effect of ligand backbone design. We find that precise engineering of the ligand backbone to integrate with the perovskite sublattice modulates the phononic structure. Computational results reveal that the optimized bidentate ligand decreases lattice reorganization compared to systems with two unlinked ligands. This ultimately manifests in higher performance of the resulting quantum emitter. The PQDs synthesized with the engineered ligands exhibit higher stability, narrower emission linewidths, decreased spectral diffusion, faster radiative rates, and an increased coherent fraction of the emitted photons, which are all parameters of critical significance for high-performance quantum light sources. 

Thus, our work marks a significant step toward the complete fundamental characterization, as well as practical application, of PQDs. The PQD system was generated through a scalable and concise synthesis, allowing production of macroscopic amounts of identical emitters, for adoption by the wider quantum photonics and quantum optics communities.  The elucidated structure-property relationships will be instrumental in future synthetic optimization toward the next generation of quantum light sources. The results also provide guidance for the design and optimization of classical light sources and photovoltaic devices based on PQDs, which have broader societal and environmental impacts. Having developed PQDs with the fastest radiative rates, lowest heterogeneous broadening, and highest coherent fraction among colloidal materials at low temperature to date should advance a host of investigations on this multifaceted material. 

A new synthetic route for InAs quantum dots (QDs) was established through this award. As opposed to previous synthetic routes employing pyrophorics, an In(I) precursor provides the necessary redox equivalents to reduce the As(III) precursor and form zincblende InAs QDs. Due to a dynamic disproportionation equilibrium of In(I) with In(0) and In(III), the rate of formation of QDs is highly tuneable with reaction temperature, and ranges from minute to hour timescales. Commercial availability and the unprecedented safety of all precursors used in the novel synthesis affords a high degree of operational simplicity and scalability. The developed approach therefore opens new possibilities for high-performance InAs QDs active in the short-wave infrared. Further, the finding of a redox equilibrium intrinsic to one of the semiconductor constituents could be adopted as a design principle in a multitude of systems. 

In addition, time-dependent density functional theory was used to study sources of surface trap states and their effect on the optical spectrum of CdSe QDs. The computational project revealed that, even for QDs with no traps in the band structure, the optical properties are still dominated by excitations associated with the surface of the QD. This provides valuable insights for the applications of CdSe QDs, and highlights the importance of using excited state methodologies for studying excited state properties.

We extended an MIT undergraduate laboratory module (5.38 Module 10) on colloidal QD research to include the materials and methods resulting from this research, and recorded video lectures and tutorials for this module. Further, we participated in the MIT ACCESS program for underrepresented minority undergraduates invited from across the nation, and used this opportunity to demonstrate the in situ growth of PQDs, as developed through this award. As per NSF?s mission, the research has advanced cutting-edge scientific knowledge, as well as participation and education in the field of science.
